description: Borrowed from Middle French bouger, from Old French bougier, from Vulgar Latin *bullicāre (“to bubble; seethe; move; stir”), from Latin bullīre (“to boil; seethe; roil”). More at boil.

verbs.description: budge (third-person singular simple present budges, present participle budging, simple past and past participle budged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move; to be shifted from a fixed position.
examples: I’ve been pushing this rock as hard as I can, but it won’t budge an inch.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move; to shift from a fixed position.
examples: I’ve been pushing this rock as hard as I can, but I can’t budge it.

entries.meaning: To yield in one’s opinions or beliefs.
examples: The Minister for Finance refused to budge on the new economic rules.

entries.meaning: (Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Indiana, western Canada) To cut or butt (in line); to join the front or middle rather than the back of a queue.
examples: Hey, no budging! Don't budge in line!

entries.meaning: To try to improve the spot of a decision on a sports field.

description: From Middle English bouge, bougie, bugee, from Anglo-Norman bogé, from Anglo-Latin *bogea, bulgia, related to Latin bulga (“a leathern bag or knapsack”). Doublet of bulge.

entries.meaning: A kind of fur prepared from lambskin dressed with the wool on, formerly used as an edging and ornament, especially on scholastic habits.
examples: They are become so liberal, as to part freely with their own budge-gowns from off their backs.
